name: Coal mine methane emissions; Production mix, surface mine
description:
This process is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  To access the library and the original dataset:
1) Navigate to the NETL LCA home page (http://www.netl.doe.gov/lca)
2) Then navigate to the “Unit Process Library” 
3) From the library, the unit process of interest can be found either through the "Complete Listing of the Unit Process Library link" or through the link to the "Unit Process Database" spreadsheet
4) For each process, a Data Sheet (DS) and Data File (DF) are available
5) Alternative parameter values can be found in the DS and/or DF

BRIEF DESCRIPTION
This parameterized dataset gives coal mine methane emissions associated with surface coal mine operations in the Powder River Basin.  Alternative parameter values can be found in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below).  Inputs and outputs are reported on the basis of 1 Item(s) of "Methane emission; Production mix, underground mine".

GOAL AND SCOPE
This parameterized unit process provides a summary of relevant output flows associated with coal mine methane emissions from surface mining. An option is provided to capture a percentage of the total methane produced, but there are no burdens associated with capturing the methane. All vented methane is assumed to be in too low a concentration to be directly flared. The reference flow of this unit process is: 1 Item(s) of "Methane emission; Production mix, underground mine".

This process is a modified version of the "Coal Mine Methane Emissions" unit process in the National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) Unit Process Database. Parameters and environmental emissions related to the oxidation of captured coal mine methane have been added. The reason that this process has no inputs is that it is treated as a service to the process, "Coal extraction; Surface mine".

This process differs slightly from the Detailed Spreadsheet Documentation (DS) file referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below.  Differences between this process and the DS are as follows:
1) Different reference flows.  This is because, in the openLCA model, coal is produced in a separate process.
2) Additional parameters and elementary flows that account for oxidation of captured methane to CO2.

BOUNDARY AND DESCRIPTION
This unit process provides the methane emissions and captured methane streams associated with coal mining operations. This unit process is used in combination with other unit processes (UPs) to provide a complete emissions profile for coal extraction. The captured methane flow can be connected to a venting and flaring UP, a compressor for injection to a natural gas pipeline, a boiler, or similar UPs.

The coal mine methane available for either emission or capture for underground coal mining was determined by adding annual vented air methane (VAM) emissions and captured/drained methane for a collection of U.S. mines (EPA, 2010). A weighted average of the available methane per kg of coal provides the expected available methane (EIA, 2009). The expected available methane for surface mine is from a single source and is included as the minimum value (EPA, 2004).

The expected percentage of captured methane was determined from the expected national VAM emissions and the total methane available. The expected capture percentage provides an emission result consistent with underground mines across the U.S. The UP can easily be configured to reflect conditions at a particular well with higher capture rates.

Additional details regarding input and output flows, including calculation methods, are available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section below).

CITATION AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION
This dataset should be cited as: 
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2015. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data - Unit Process: Coal mine methane emissions; Production mix, surface mine. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last updated: September 2015 (Version 1). Retrieved on [DATE] from [URL for this dataset].

This dataset is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  The Library offers additional information concerning this dataset in the form of a Detailed Spreadsheet  Documentation (DS) file and a Process Documentation File (DF).  The DS file  is an Excel file that contains all of the parameters, inputs, and outputs for a given system as well as background data, calculations and quality scores.  The DF file is a PDF document that contains major assumptions and data sources that are the basis for each unit process.  The NETL Unit Process Library is located on the NETL website (netl.doe.gov) under Research / Energy Analysis / Energy Trends and Issues / Life Cycle Analysis / Unit Process Library.

Full citations for the DS and DF are given below.

DS File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2013. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data - Unit Process: Coal Mine Methane Emissions. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last updated: 2015 (Version 2). Retrieved on 09/30/2015 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DS_Stage1_O_Coal_Mine_Methane_2013-02.xlsx.

DF File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2013. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data - Unit Process: Coal Mine Methane Emissions. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last updated: 2015 (Version 2). Retrieved on 09/30/2015 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DF_Stage1_O_Coal_Mine_Methane_2013-02.docx.

category.name: Bit. Coal and Lignite Surface Mining

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This data set is representative of best available public data from 01/01/2009 to 12/31/2009 and is not subject to limited usability within sub-time spans (e.g. summer, winter).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription:
This unit process provides a summary of relevant input and output flows associated with coal mine methane emissions.  Vented air methane emissions are based on methane emissions from surface and underground coal mines in the U.S.  All vented methane is assumed to be in too low a concentration to be directly flared. 

Additional details regarding input and output flows, including calculation methods, are available in the associated documentation (referenced in the Citation and Associated Documentation section in the Description field).
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: All elementary and technosphere flows are calculated on a functional unit basis. Calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful work are done using lower heating values (LHV) and calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful heat are done using higher heating values (HHV). Unless explicitly stated in the associated reference documents applicable calculations assumed standard atmospheric temperature and pressure (SATP).
processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription:

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: This is a gate-to-gate unit process and can be used for any type of LCA study.

parameters.name: capture_frac
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Adjustable parameter - percent of coal mine methane captured (or drained)

parameters.name: cmm
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Adjustable parameter - mass of coal mine methane per kg of produced coal available for venti

parameters.name: oxidation_frac
parameters.description: [dimensionless] Adjustable parameter - percent of methane that is oxidized to CO2

parameters.name: flare_CO2
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Carbon dioxide emissions from captured methane that is flared

parameters.name: flare_CH4
parameters.description: [kg/kg] Methane emissions from captured methane that is flared
